title: Polish factory worker laid off ‘because of Brexit uncertainty’
text:
Factory worker Sebastian Gajda said he received a letter ‘out of the blue’ telling him his contract was being terminated (Picture: MEN Media)

A Polish factory worker says his contract with a UK manufacturer is being terminated due to his boss’s fears over Brexit.

Sebastian Gajda, 25, had been hoping to secure a permanent position with Bartoline after joining the Beverley-based company, which makes decorating products, on a temporary contract last December.

But he was ‘angry and shocked’ to receive a letter ‘out of the blue’ last week informing him he would not be kept on ‘due to issues around Brexit’.

Mr Gajda said: ‘It was a huge shock to me.

‘I had been in almost every day so I assumed there was plenty of work.’

The letter says the firm is about to enter ‘a potential turbulent time with the exit from the EU’ (Picture: MEN Media)

The letter, from fillers and adhesives production manager Charles Weston, says: ‘The business is about to enter a potential turbulent time with the exit from the EU.

‘While we do not expect any long term issues, we may experience a dip in orders as we enter the changeover period.

‘To ensure that we are in the best position to deal with any change, it is with regret that I will need to terminate your contract.

‘I would like to thank you for your hard efforts in the past and wish you all the best in securing another suitable position.’

Mr Gajda, from Hull, was given an extra week’s notice beyond the statutory week, but he is still ‘angry’ at having to find a new job having only just begun ‘settling down here’.

‘I am angry as this came out of the blue,’ he told Hull Live. ‘There was no indication my job was under threat.

‘Even though I have come from Poland I was not that worried about Brexit, so it is a huge shock to find I have been so directly affected.

‘I don’t know of any other workers at the company who have lost their jobs because of this.

‘I have no plans to return to Poland and I will just have to try and find a new job. I have just bought new car insurance and I was settling down here.’

Alexandra Jastrzebska, who runs the Polish Bureau in Hull, said she was also shocked by the letter.

She added: ‘I have never seen anything like this before and I couldn’t believe Brexit was given as a reason to lose your job. This seems to me to be an awful reason and I worry whether it will happen to anyone else.

‘We don’t know if it is Polish or eastern Europeans that are at risk or is it English people too?

‘I just hope the Polish community are not being targeted as we pay our taxes and contribute to the community and love being here.’

Bartoline has been contacted for comment.

description: Sebastian Gajda, 25, had been hoping to secure a permanent position with Bartoline, but will not be kept on ‘due to issues around Brexit’.
